div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
REVOLT IN CAUCASUS. TURKISH AGITATORS ACTIVE. BALAKHANY BURNT DOWN. BRITISH SUBJECTS BESIEGED.
div.p: St. Petersburg, September 8. The revolt in the Caucasus was planned long ago and carefully organised. It is fomented by Turkish agitators bearing the green standard. Bands of peasants are invading the domains of the nobles and seizing firearms. (Reuter)

Baku, September 8. The British subjects have escaped on board the steamers. It is believed that the Russian authorities are now paying dearly for their policy in inciting the Tartars against the Armenians. The former are now attacking all the Christians. Four British subjects are besieged in a house at Balakhany. The Governor of Baku declares that he is powerless to help them. (Reuter)
TIFLIS, September 8. The Tartars are surrounding Baku. Balakhany has been totally destroyed by fire.(Havas)

div.head: THE TOKIO RIOTS. MARTIAL LAW PROCLAIMED.
div.p: Tokio, September 8. Martial law has been proclaimed. The disorders were resumed yesterday evening. The troops are guarding the Foreign Legations.(Reuter)

Tokio, September 8. The newspapers deplore the excesses committed here, which contrast with the admirable serenity shown during the war. The town was quiet to-day and no serious disturbances took place anywhere during the night The party leaders met and agreed to urge the Cabinet to call a special Diet as the best means of restoring quietness. (Reuter)
Tokio, September 8. A state of siege has been declared here.(Havas)

div.head: TERRIBLE EARTHQUAKE IN ITALY. THREE TOWNS DESTROYED.
div.p: Rome, September 8. A violent earthquake took place this morning throughout Italy, and particularly in Calabria where there were many deaths The towns of Pizzo, Monteleone, and Martirano have been almost completely destroyed. (Reuter)
Catanzaro, September 8. 347 persons were killed in Calabria owing to the earthquake. More than a down towns and villages were partially wrecked. (Reuter)
Rome, September 8. An earthquake in Calabria has killed several hundreds of persons.(Havas)

div.head: THE MOROCCO QUESTION. ROUVIER AND ROSEN MEET.
div.p: Paris, September 8. M. Rouvier and M. Rosen have commenced their conferences over the Morocco question.(Havas)

div.head: THE FAMINE IN RUSSIA. MEANS OF RELIEF.
div.p: St. Petersburg, September 8. The first sitting of the Ministerial Conference to consider the question of granting relief to the famine stricken provinces, recommended the Treasury to assign £4,000,000 for the purchase of cereals.(Reuter)

div.head: KING EDWARD AT MARIENBAD.
div.p: London, September 8. King Edward has left Marienbad. His health has much improved.(Reuter)

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: Vienna, September 8. The Khedive has left for Constantinople.(Reuter)

div.head: THE CHANNEL SQUADRON.
div.p: Copenhagen, September 8. The Channel Squadron has arrived here.(Reuter)

div.head: Sanitary Department
div.p: Dr. Jacob Daond baa been authorised to practise his profession in Egypt.

div.head: FOUND DROWNED
div.p: The body of a European, aged about forty, was picked up on the eastern beach yesterday morning.

div.head: The Plague
div.p: Yesterday bulletin reports the admission to hospital of a shawish of the Labban quarter, Alexandria. One recovery is also reported.

div.head: Cart Accident
div.p: A boy named Zehi Moham-ed was run over by a cart yesterday near the Custom House and will require three weeks medical treatment

div.head: Stray and Ownerless Dogs
div.p: found in the Mouski district of Cairo during to-morrow night and at dawn of the 11th inst will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: Theft by a Moawkn
div.p: The moawen of Teh el Baroud poet office has been sentenced to two years imprisonment by the Alexandria Assize Courts for having stolen a sum of L.E. 81, which was deposited in the post office savings

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 82 vessels passed through the Canal on the 5th and 6th inst., 14 of which were British, 5 German, 1 French, 2 Dutch. The receipts for the two days were frs. 605,595.76, making the total from the 1st inst frs. 1,756,207.58.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail
div.p: will be made up at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 8-30 a.m. on Monday for ordinary correspondence. Registered letters must be banded in by 9 p.m. on Sunday, and insured articles, money orders, and parcels by noon on that day.

div.head: Theft at Cairo Station
div.p: A purse containing £10 was stolen from the pocket of Sheikh Abdul Rahmin Selim, inspector of kuttabs, Ministry of Public Instruction, at Cairo station yesterday. The police are making every endeavour to discover the pickpocket.

div.head: Quarrel Ends in Bloodshed
div.p: Hassanein Mohamed and Ramadan Muni, a Sais, quarel- at Ramleh yesterday. The first named being in liquor stabbed bis enemy in the ride inflicting very serious injuries. The culprit has been arrested.

div.head: Sanitary Inspection
div.p: Our Akhmin Correspondent informs us that Dr. Garner, chief inspector of Upper Egypt in the Sanitary Department, arrived there on Tuesday and made a visit of inspection round the town and at the offices of the administration. He toft for Sohag on the conclusion of his inspection.

div.head: The Alhambra Theatre
div.p: Cesareo's five-act tragedy Francesca da Rimini is billed for this evening, and this will be the first occasion upon which the company has presented it in Alexandria. The tragedy will be followed by a farce, entitled La Vedova delle Camelie. At tomorrow afternoon's matinée, commencing at 3 p.m., Prestame tua Moglie will be staged, and at the evening performance Strega Bianca e Strega Nera and El Catino di Campagna will be played.

div.head: Sax Stefano Casino
div.p: To-night is the oo-oasion of the grand fete at San Stefano Casino. The programme includes an orchestral and vocal concert, firework display, and, at 11 p.m. a small dance. The vocal part of the concert which commences at 10 p.m., will include the whole of the third act of Puccini's La Boheme, and the trio and finale of the third act of Verdi's Ernani. On Sunday the last of the vocal concerts will be given, and will consist of those pieces which have proved the most popular at previous concerts

div.head: Alexandria Tramways
div.p: We are asked to give notice that the tramcars running on the St Catherine Karmous line will, from the 15th inst., leave the two terminal points every ten minutes, instead of every twenty as heretofore. From the same date, the half feres will be supressed, and the charges will be 10 millièmes first elan and 5 millièmes second class. There will also be a modification in the evening timetable of the Mex line from the 18th inst, after which date the last departure from Rond-Point for Max will be at 9 p.m., for Gabbari at 9 30 p.m., and from Mex to the town at 10 p.m.

div.head: British Chamber of Commerce
div.p: We would draw the attention of manufacturers and merchants to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, which was formed in 1896 with the sole object of assisting British trade in this country. The services of the Chamber are always at the disposal of any member desiring information on trade matters generally, including the question of appointing suitable agents. As no fee is charged for such advice, it is obviously in the interests of all British traders here to become members, especially when it is remembered that the annual subscription is merely the nominal one of £1. 'The latter payment also includes a copy of the monthly Journal issued by the Chamber Home inquirers can obtain further particulars from our London office, 36 New Broad-street, which acts as agents to the Chamber.

div.head: THE SOCIETE DES SUCRERIES. HON. A J, DAVEY INTERVIEWED.
div.p: Through the courtesy of the Hon. A. J. Davey we are enabled to place before our readers the exact position at this moment of the above company, whose shares have been so greatly depreciated on our, local bourses since the receipt of the news of the tragic end of its late chairman. When this became known several sinister rumours wore set afloat, and, as we stated in a previous issue, the fact that no definite news was forthcoming at that time as to whether the Sucreries would eventually be losers by the catastrophe that had led to M. Cronier’s sad suicide brought about the great and sudden depreciation of the shares which took place. Up to the present the company has paid regular and handsome dividends, the last being at the rate of 8 per cent, and carrying over about £2,600 to this year’s account. The net profit for the twelve months ending 31st October last was no less than L.E. 76,780, after payment of interest on the debentures and all other charges, so that until M. Cronier’s failure, the company’s affairs were in a prosperous state. In reply to enquiries made by our representative, Mr. Davey said that as regards the bills for some 24 million francs drawn on the Sucreries by the succession Henri Say, the company would probably contest their validity, and the question was one for the law courts to decide. In the meanwhile the Hon. A. Davey acting in the capacity of general manager, and in the name of the company, had applied for a concordat preventif, or a stay of execution, and the Commercial Chamber of the Mixed Tribunal in Cairo will meet on the 19th instant to consider the application. In the meanwhile there are ample funds in hands to meet all payments, a sum of no less than £12,000 haring been disbursed only two days back, which fact completely refutes the adverse rumours spread that the company's offers were empty. Monsieur Girard, the head accountant, is busily engaged preparing a full and detailed statement to be presented to the pretiding judge of the Commercial Chamber on the date when the application will come up for consideration. Until then every account as it becomes due will be met at once in cash, and Mr. Davey has given orders that the utmost economy most be practised in every department until the decision of the Court becomes known. "It would be unfortunate, indeed, it would in fact be nothing less than a calamity,” said Mr. Davey, “should the company at this juncture have to suspend operations, for the very good and simple reason that its suspension would spell ruin to many cultivators of sugar cane in Upper Egypt. Once its factories were closed the next crop would be practically valueless. The company bad entered into a contract with the Dalra Sanieh Co., for the supply of 12 million cantars of cane at P.T. 3 per kantar, to be delivered between now and March next, and this large quantity, as well as that of private individuals, would be lost” It does great credit to Mr. Davey to bave temporarily withdrawn his resignation, which he had sent in before the Cromer crash occur-red, now that the company is in temporary difficulties. As regards the resignation of Messrs. A. Leroux and de La Bouglise which has been rumoured of late, nothing is yet known at the head office in Cairo. Maltre Carton de Wiart the company's legal adviser, is expected back in a few days and it is hoped that with his advent everything will be arranged to enable the Société des Sucreries to continue its career, and this hope we most sincerely endorse, as much in the interest of the shareholders as in that of the fellaheen, who supply the cane for the factories. We may add that if the concordat is granted the names of Sir Elwin Palmer, Harari Pasha, and probably M. Dubourg, a French gentleman well known in Cairo, will be submitted as liquidators. It would, in oar opinion, be impossible to make a better choice.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: The Council of Ministers, meeting on the 7th inst. at San Stefano, declared the following undertakings to be of public utility :- The construction of light railway lines, from Kuesfa to Minet el Gamh in the Sharkieh and Dakhalieh provinces, and from Sakha to Sidi Salem in Gharbieh province. The construction of a branch line between Nag Hamadi and the Nile in Keneh province. The bridging of the Ibrahimieh canal, Assiout province, at the three villages of Manfalout, Narali Ganouleh and Beni Korreh. Other decisions deal with the expropriation etc. of land, and do not possess any great public interest

div.head: THE LATE CAPTAIN REES.
div.p: The funeral of Captain Rees, chief signaller at Kom-el Nadours, took place at 9.30 am. this morning. The funeral service was held at St. Mark’s Church, the Rev. R. Wormell, M.A.,officiating. The coffin was then taken to the cemetery, the bearers for part of the way being European employés at the signal station. H.B.M’s Vice-Consul, Sir R M. Blomfield, Mr. Sergeant of the Khedivial Mail S.S. Co., Mr. Percy Smith, of the Prince S.S. Line, Mr. Roberta, Mr. Orsi, representing Lloyd’s Agency, and many others were present at the red ceremony, with a guard of honor con- sisting of about twenty tailors of the Porta and Lights Administration and the Khedivial Mail S.S Co.

div.head: CONSULAR REPORTS ON EGYPT. PORT SAID.
div.p: In his report on the trade of Port Said in 1904 Mr. Cameron, after giving tables of exports and imports, to some of which we will revert later, remark* that the ohief point of interest in the export tables is the steady increase of the quantity of cotton exported. In 1901 8,066 kantars of a value of LE. 5,246 left Port Said and Ismailia. The export increased enormously in 1902, and in 1904 amounted no less than 89,480 kantars valued at L.E. 244,790. This cotton came from the Sharkieh province, being brought from Zsgazig, as a rule, down the sweet-water canal to Ismailia and being then put on board steamers on Lake Timsah. An increase of rolling stock and the opening of the new boat service across Lake Menzaleh will probably bring cotton to Port said in quantities sufficient to justify shippers in chartering steamers, many of which would be available after discharging coal at the port. The total import trade of Port Said in 1904 amounted in value to LE. 1,869,290. Turkey with a trade of LE. 466,490 was the leading contributer, followed by the United Kingdom (L E. 287.280) and France (LE. 197,200). We need not inform our readers that almost the whole export trade of Palestine, Syria, and Southern Asia Minor comes to Port Said, which explains the preponderance of Ottoman imports, which at first sight is a little perplexing. Coal imports showed an increase of some 70,000 tons, and the author of the report notes the increased proportion of German coal in that supplied by the Deutsches Kohlen Deput of Bremen to the principal German lines of steamers in transit Of the exports in 1904 some 55 % went to the United Kingdom, Germany with about 31 % coming second. In discussing the future of the port, Mr. Cameron makes the following interesting re marks -.—“With the opening of the ordinary gauge government railway on June 1, 1904, a new ere of prosperity has begun for Port Said. The journey to Cairo has been -shortened to fire hours and the number of daily trains has been increased both for goods and passengers, thus enabling the town to cope with the large and increasing demands of the traffic in connection with the thousands of tourists who pass through Port Said in the winter season. Another important project is approaching completion ; the New Egyptian and the Men-xaleh Canal and Navigation Companies have obtained a concession for making a deep and wide channel across the shallow water of Lake Menzalaeh, in order to establish a daily service of steam ferry boats of shallow draught between Kharputi (Port Said) and Matarieh, the eastern point of the fertile district of Mansou-rah rah. The journey would take about throe hours, and in co-operation with the light railway which has its termination at Matarieh, this proposed route across the lake ought to prove of the greatest value in connecting Port Said with the interior of the Delta.” In discusing the transit of belligerent vessels, during the war that has just closed, Mr. Cameron states that the total Russian force that passed through the canal amounted to three battleships, three coast defence ships, seven cruisers, eleven destroyers and seventeen transports. Very few merchantmen were actually detained by their passage, and those that were detained at Suez when homeward bound, were granted extra facilities through the canal on the following day. The work of deepening the canal progresses steadily, as may be shown by the increase of the maximum draught allowed. Till the end of 1901 this did not exceed 95 feet 7 inches. On January 1901, the maximum draught was raised to 8 metres (26 feet 3 inches) and on January 1 1906 it will be raised to 27 feet On the same date the tariff for laden ships will be reduced to 7 francs 75 c. The conclusions at which the author arrives re British shipping are very satisfactory. The percentage of British vessels using the canal has risen from 56 percent, in 1901 to 63-2per cent in 1904, and their net tonnage from 57-8 per cent in 1901 to 65.9 per cent. last year. These figures apply only to the general total of 4,937 vessels ; but if we consider only mer-chant vessels, the British percentages have risen daring the last four years from 67 to 74 per cent in number and from 71 to 76 per cent in net tonnage, or three-quarters of the mercantile traffic of the Canal. During the last three years the percentages of German vessels have been 12-9 per cent in 1902, 13-1 per cent in 1903 and 19-8 per cent in 1904 ; and of their net tonnage 15-2 per cent in 1909, 14 9 in 1903 and 14-7 in 1904. France, the Netherlands, Norway. Austria-Hungary, and Italy combined furnish a total of 10.5 per cent of the vessels and 8.7 per cent, of the tonnage These facts are reassuring, and show that the British mercantile marine is more than holding its own in the Canal traffic. A proof of this may be seen in the table of the great companies which use the Canal Of these 40, 27 are British, 5 German, 3 French, 9 Dutch, and 1 each Autro-Hunga-rian, Italian, and Spanish.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL. Restaurant.
div.p: Table d'Hete Luncheons and Dinners served on the Terrace ORCHESTRA PLAYS 6 TO 11.30 PM

div.head: SMYRNA CONSPIRACY. THE DISCOVERY OF BOMBS.
div.p: The "Eastern Press,” an Armenian weekly paper, published in Smyrna, gives the following details of the discovery of bombs in that city Thanks to the vigilance of the Governor of Smyrna, H.E. Kiamil Pasha, the Armenian revolutionary movement was detected before any great harm had been done, and what promised to become a series of bomb outrages has been checked. The police, who had discovered the meeting place of the revolutionaries, surrounded the house, which is situated in the Greek quarter, Tabahine, but word had reached the conspirators, and they managed to escape. The house was however, searched by the police, and eighty large bombs, with chemicals and apparatus, and three clock-work wore found on the premises. All of there were seized and taken to the palace for examination. Several searches were subsequently made in houses in the St. Dimitri Greek quarter, and several person* were arrested on suspicion of having manufactured these infernal machines. A spatial committee, under the presidency of Kiamil Pasha, has been appointed to con-duct investigations into the characters of inspected persons and to march houses. One hundred and eighty persons have been arrested up to the present, but eighty of there were released after being examined. The reports appearing in the Athens papers describing the arrest of two thousand are grossly exaggerated. As the result of the investigations it is con-oluded that the movement is entirely a revo-lutionary one instigated by Armenians from other countries and that they hope to excite the sympathy of their fellow countrymen in Smyrna by this means, but the Armenians here are, as a rule, loyal subjects of the Sultan. The people can rest assured that the Government will do all in their power to put a stop to this state of affairs and restore the normal tranquillity of the city. The assassin of the late Baliozian has been hung as an example to other plotters. The number of police agents has been increased by fifty, so that the work of checking attempt* at outrage may be more effectively carried out. Many of them bare left for the villages inland by special train accompanied by the chief of the police.

div.head: THE NILE FLOOD.
div.p: The condition of the Nile flood has improved distinctly in the last month, and though it cannot be regarded as a high Nile, the readings of the various gauges, which we receive, do not compare unfavorably with those of last year. In some cases higher readings are shown, whilst in others they are somewhat lower, but the difference in no instance is remarkable. The measures which have been taken by the Ministry of Public Works will happily, avert any danger of the country suffering from a shortage of crops and the perfection to which the irrigation of the country has been brought is of great credit to Sir William Garstin, Mr. Webb, Mr. Verschoyle, and their subor-dinates.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: We are glad to be able to report that Mr. Rowland Snelling, editor and manager of the "Egyptian Gazette” is making rapid strides towards a complete recovery, and is expected to return to Egypt early in October at the latest.
M. A. Chelu Bey left for Marseilles yesterday by the M M. Senegal
A contemporary announces that M. Charles Labusiere, formerly agent of the Messageries Maritimes S.S. Co., in Cairo, has been made Knight of the Legion of Honor.
Mr. J. Caftari left for Europe yesterday.

The following visitors are staying at the Beau-Rivage Hotel Ramleh : Mr. and Mrs. John Bell, Major and Mrs. W.H. Rotheram, Mr. and Mrs. Nicolas Bey Boutros, Mr. and Mrs. H. Nacghton, Mr. R. Dracopoulos, Miss W. Sells, Mire L Crowther, H Khaloussi Bey, M. Refand Bey, Mr. and Mrs. M.. Materia, Miss L Stevens, Mme N. Rhally, Miss F. Scholthausen, Miss R Tedeschi, Mr. and Mrs. H. Dasso, Mr. and Mrs LM. Ades and family, Mr. G. Métrai Mr. P. Denerias.

div.head: Passenger List
div.p: DEPARTURES.

Le paquebot Sénégal des Messageries Maritimes parti hier pour Marseille avait a bord : M.M. A. Cbelu Bey.Moh. Amin. Mme J. P. Davies, lient Langlois, lient Leodos.. Sami Torudini, R. P. Domon. B. P. Bernard,Bourget, Sohambrial Soné, Penaud et Nou risse, Cbelu Bey fiU, Loub Favre Ameen G Korenm, Bourgeois, Boyaub J. B.. Caffari, Mire L. Osman, Sednaoui. Stephany, Mme Gaty, R.P. Guitton, Bonot San ton, de Belinay, Gaillard et Dallai Frère G. Lallemand, Axkdaki, Emile Fanons, Axis Ibrahim et 31 passengers de se et 4e classes.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: La conclusion de la paix ruaso-japonaise avait deja amené la banne et l’activité dans les bonnes da monde sotisr, lorsque la krach des Sucreries est venu soudain démoraliser la spéculation, particulièrement à Paris et en Egypte Le marasme et b réaction ont auasiu.t succédé à l’animation naisante. Les valanrs étrangère. ribs-reérecs en out subi le contrecoup Comme la publie égyptien ne s est guère engagé dans les Sucreries qu’à partir du cours da 170 jusqu’à 990 pour se faire une moyenne lorsque la prix est tombé à 150, on évalue les pertes subies ici à deux ou trois cent y'iu livras. Plusieurs banques en ont raresati la leooores, mais oomma la presque totalité de leur clients sont solvables, il leur suffire de prendre patience pour rentrer dan* leurs fonds, Il va sans dire qu’avec une liquidation fotoée las actionnaires n trouveraient rectifiée, qu'avec la oonoordat préventif, que tout le monda repère, les ohosas s' arrangeront au mieux dre intérêts non reniement des actionnaires mais encore de tout le marché. qui dans. ce cas ne tardera pas à se relever. Les Banques continuent à faire qualques difficultés pour accorder des avances sur titres, la saison cotonnière s'annon cant comma excep-tionnellement favorable. L’Agricole ouvre à U 1/32, atteint 14 7/16 pour retomber vers la fin à 14 5/16 achetaurs. De 9 9/16 la Nouvelle flechit à 9 1/2. L’ex-right monte de 9 13/16 à 9 29/32 pour revenir à 9 13/16 en clôture. Comme avant la nouvelle émission l’Agricole était à 11 £, nombre de spéculateurs trouvent que le prix de 10 ou 10 1/2 n’au rait en oe moment rien d'exagéré. Si, en effet, le Capital action a été doublé, la capital obligation* l’a été également. II n’y a donc rien de changé dans la situation antérieure, da nature à justifier la bas prix actuel et il y a tout lieu da croire qu’une poussee s'effectuera à la rentrée des capitalistes d’Europe. De 27 1/2 la Banque Nationale hausse à 97 8/4 pour retomber an cluture à 27 6/8. L'éoart entre la nouvelle et l’aneiame au profit da celle-ci, passe da 1/8 à 8/16 et ne tardera pas à prendre dre proportions plus importantes A Londres la National est toujours en faveur à 27 3/4. Les Actions Crédit Foncier fléchissent de 891 à 816 pour reprendre à 890, aveo à la hausse. Après avoir fléchi un moment de 180 à 178, la Came di Soonto ne tarde pas à ne relever jusqu'à 183. La Banque d'Athènes fluctue entre 127 1/9 et 198 et clôture ferme à 197 1/9. De très importantes transactions plusieurs milliers par jour, ont eu lieu en Estates à un oours variant da 1 7/32 à 1 9/32. Ia clôture a'effectue à 1 1/4 acheteure. De plus hants prix sont an perspective. Le Trust art également en bonne tendance à 1 8/8 vendeurs. Pa oontre, l'Investment est. plutôt faible Le cours tombe de 1 9/32 à 1 7/32 pour finir kl 1/4 D'excellentes affaires auraient été, dit-on, faites per la New Egyptien, dont la prix hausse de 31/ à 33/9 pour finir è 33 acheteurs, aveotendance à la hausse. La Salt and Soda monte de 34/6 à 35/3 et cloture à 35. La Markets sont très soutenus entre 24/1 1/2 et 24/4 1/2 prix auquel on clôture acheteurs. La peste bovine étant sur le point de disparaître du pays, on dit que la réouverture des marchés à bestiaux ne serait plu qu'une De 5/4 la Cotton Mills remontent à 5/10 1/2 et 6. On clôture à 5/9 acheteurs.Les Eaux du Caire fléchissent de 1175 à 1165. La Behera réactionne également da 43 1/2 à 49 1/2 sans transactions. Après-avoir fléchi de 6 1/4 a 5 3/16, l’Uihaias remonta à 6 11/22 en clôture. Tandis que U Nungovieh tombe de 10 7/16 à 10 5/16 l’Upper Egypt monte da 5 1/16 à 5 3/16. Il convient cependant dire que le cours est inférieur de 1/8 pou cette derniere valeur, si b prix de l’action est intégralment versé. L'Anglo American Nile est ferme a 5 1/2. La Khédivial Mail Ordinary monta de 90/6 à 22/- en clôture. De 213 b Crown Brewery reprend rare la fin à 220. Après avoir repris un moment de 27 1/2 à 27 7/8 la Daira retombe en clôtnre à 27 5/8. En somme, ou derniers jours n’ont pu été suai brillante que b faisait entrevoir b oon otosion de b paix, mais comme b ceua de cette situation provient nniquemaut du Krach des Suoreriss, une reprise est certaine dès que les premières difficultés auront été surmontées.
(Auiourd i midi d demie)

Ce matin notre marché est beaoooop mieux sou tou les rapporte. Ia plupart des valeur* •ont en hausse et ont donné ben à un mouvement arecs actif. On aohète b National Bank à 97 6/8 l’an-etane rt 971/9 b nouvelle, et b Delta Iigfatà 18 5/16. Las Estâtes gagnent toujours du tanin at sont plu que jamais recherchés à 1 1/4. Les noüvelles sont excellentes. Les actions Crédit Foncier s'avancait de 817 à 890,l’Agricole de U 3/16 à 14 3/8, b Banque d'Athènes de 197 .1/9 à 199 1/4, b New-Egyptien da 32/3 à 33/3 l’Ordinary Khédivial Mail à 22/3. b Privilégiée Tramways d’Alexandrie de 160 à 161 et b Ramleh Raüway de 7 1/16 à 7 8/16 acheteurs Par contre, les Markets fléehisreut de 24/6 h 24/3 et b Daim de 97 5/8 à 27 19/39. Un reeul aanribb a lieu pour las Sucruies de 52 a 46 ; le cours reaetienne également a Paris jusqu'à 51.
